He hauled lumber from there with a wagon

and a pair of mules that insisted on running

away most every day. Lots of prairie chicken

and coyotes were in the mesquite that grew in

the pasture. Three children were born while

they lived in Hardeman County: Annie in

1911, R.D. Jr. in 1913 and Allie Fay in 1915.

In May 1917 they moved to Deaf Smith

County, buying a half section of land three

and one half miles northwest of Summerfield.

They built a house there and farmed with

horses for several years.

Farming was rough during the dust bowl

days. There was a time when the government

paid farmers to destroy some of their cattle

because there was no feed for them.

Bob and Addie sold their farm in 1942 and

moved to Hereford. In 1946 Bob broke his hip

in a fall and never walked again. He died

Christmas Eve in 1950. Addie died in April

1968. They are both buried in West Park

Cemetery in Hereford.

All three children went to school at Summerfield.

Annie finished at Canyon College

High School as there was no high school at

Summerfield for two years. R.D. and Allie

Fay finished at Summerfield later.

Annie married George DeLozier and they

moved to Tennessee, his home state, in 1930.

Allie Fay married Jack Streun in 1935.

They farmed in Castro County. Two sons, Joe

and Gene, were born to them. Joe passed

away in 1971. Gene works at the Hereford

post office. Allie Fay passed away in 1967.

R.D. married Christine Atchley in 1940. In

1942 R.D. entered World War II. He spent

fourteen months in the States and in 1943

spent five months in Africa and on to Italy,

staying two years. He was discharged in 1945.

He landed in New York and took a train to El

Paso where he was met by his wife and a

brother-in-law. He is retired and they live in

Hereford and Christine is employed at Penney's

Department Store.

ANNIE

LANCE DeLOZIER

Joe H. Landers

Joe H. Landers moved his family to Hereford

in the fall of 1925 from Schoolton,

Oklahoma. The Landers had sold their holdings

there, moving here to join Mrs. Landers

parents, the R.M. Gunns, who had come to

Hereford from Curry County, New Mexico

earlier in the same year.

Mr. Landers farmed with his father-in-law

and worked for Hawkins' Produce during the

slack farming season until 1927 when they

moved to Summerfield to operate the grocery

store and post office there in partnership with

Tom Hartley.

In 1928 they moved to the Westway community

to again farm with Mr. Gunn. They

purchased the farm from Mr. Gunn in the

1940's and are still residents of the Westway

Community.

Weathering the "dust bowl" days and the

depression took a lot of sacrificing and living

from the land. They had their own milk

supply, a big garden from which they canned

during the summer months to carry them

through the winter months. They had their

chickens and had "butchering days" annually

for their supply of meat for the year. They

also canned their sausage and some beef to

preserve it until the fall of the next year. They

hauled a load of wheat to the .mill in Hereford

and had their own flour ground and stored it

for the winter.

The Landers have been active in all community

affairs over the years. Mr. Landers

drove a school bus and was on the school

board for a time when there was school at

Westway.

Mrs. Landers was a charter member of the

Westway Home Demonstration Club and

was involved in all activities connected with

the club. She was a member of the Home

Demonstration Council Choir which was

active in Hereford for a number of years.

They have both been active church workers

over the years, having served in various

church offices and filled Sunday School

department teachers' positions. Mr. Landers

has been a deacon in the Westway Baptist

Church since 1935.

Joseph Henry Landers was born July 27,

1901 in Choctaw, Oklahoma. Lola May

Gunn Landers was born December 29, 1903

in Woods County, Oklahoma. They were

married October 9, 1920 in Schoolton,

Oklahoma.

They have three children, Roy M. Landers

born August 28, 1921 in Curry County, New

Mexico, Vesta Mae Landers Nunley born

August 11, 1924 also in Curry County, and

Ross Joe Landers born January 16, 1939 in

Hereford.

Roy M. Landers

The custom of family generation living

near one another brought Roy and Pauline

Landers to the Texas Panhandle. Roy's

grandparents, the R.M. Gunns, moved from

Schoolton, Oklahoma to Hollene, New Mexico.

There Roy Marshall, first child of Joe and

Lola (Gunn) Landers was born Aug. 28,

1921. In the fall of 1925 they moved to

Hereford with their children, Roy and Vesta

Mae. The R.M. Gunns had already moved to

Hereford and settled in a house at the west

end of Norton Street.

The Joe Landers moved to Summerfield

and Roy started to school there. In 1928 the

family moved to Westway, where Roy

attended school through the eighth grade. He

went to high school in Hereford in the building

that is now Stanton Junior High. Students

furnished their own transportation into Hereford.
